dataset.title: Fog and Precipitation Chemistry at a Mid-land Forest in Central Taiwan

address.deliveryPoint: 台北市大安區和平東路一段162號

abstract.para: We analyzed fog and bulk precipitation chemistry at a cloud forest in central Taiwan where mountain agriculture activities are highest. Th ere were 320 foggy days (visibility <1000 m) recorded between April 2005 and March 2006. Fog was most frequent between April 2005 and July 2005 and in March 2006 (153/153 d) and least frequent in January 2006 (21/31 d). Th e total fog duration was 2415 h, representing 28% of the sampling period. Compared with bulk precipitation, fog was disproportionally enriched in NO3– and SO42– relative to K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, and NH4+, resulting in higher a content of nitric acid and sulfuric acid than weak acids or neutral salts and, therefore, higher acidity (median pH, 4.9) in fog than in bulk precipitation (median and mean pH, 5.5). Th e very high input of NH4+ (47 kg N ha–1 yr–1) through bulk precipitation suggests that the use of fertilizer (ammonium sulfate and animal manure) associated with mountain agriculture has a major impact on atmospheric deposition at the surrounding forest ecosystems. Th e input of inorganic N reached 125 kg N ha–1 yr–1 and likely exceeded the biological demand of the forest ecosystem. Sulfate is the most abundant anion in fog at Chi-tou and in precipitation at various forests throughout Taiwan, suggesting that the emission and transport of large quantities of SO2, the precursor of SO42–, is an island-wide environmental issue.

section.para: Th e collecting unit contains 536 vertical Tefl on strands, which are 13.8 cm long and 0.5 mm in diameter, spaced 0.6 mm apart. Visibility was detected every 2 min. When the visibility fell below 1000 m, the datalogger sent a signal to turn on the fog collector. Th e fog collector drew in fog using a 25-cm-diameter fan (fl ow rate 1760 m3 h–1) and collected water on the Tefl on strands by inertial impaction. Th e positioning of the air inlet on the bottom of the sampler makes it possible to avoid collecting rain. Fog water was directed into a 600-mL polyethylene bottle by gravity through a fl uoropolymer tube (Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp., Taipei, Taiwan). A polypropylene bucket (29.7 cm diameter) was set up on the top of the meteorological tower to collect bulk precipitation.

Between April 2005 and March 2006, fog water in the collection bottle was retrieved on a weekly basis at 2:00 pm on each Saturday. Th e volume of fog water was measured in the field and poured into a polyethylene bottle (10–250 mL depending on the volume of water). Bulk precipitation was collected immediately after the collection of the fog sample each week. During collection, the volume of rain water was measured, and a 250-mL subsample was taken in a polyethylene bottle. All water samples were refrigerated at 4°C before chemical analyses.
All bottles used for water samples were rinsed with deionized water before use. The Teflon strands, the tubing, and the bucket were rinsed with deionized water after each collection.

Samples were brought back to National Changhua University of Education, with the pH measured on unfi ltered samples using a Corning 430 pH meter. Samples were transported to the water chemistry laboratory of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute within 3 d. To avoid alterations to chemical composition, all samples were refrigerated

and analyzed within 1 mo of collection. Filtered samples (Gelman Science GN-6 grid 0.45-μm sterilized fi lter paper) were analyzed for anions and cations, including Cl–, NO3 –, SO4 2–, Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, and NH4 +, using ion chromatography. Alkalinity was determined by titration with 0.005 mol L−1 H2SO4 to pH 4.52. Internal standard solutions used for linearity calibration of each ion were prepared by diluting 1000 mg L–1 Merck standard solutions into a series of concentrations bracketing the range of sample concentrations (Merck Taiwan, Taipei, Taiwan).

methodStep.instrumentation: ion chromatography (Dionex DX-100; Dionex Corp., Sunnyvale, CA).
